questions.stem: Strangles is best described as:

options.label: A
options.text: A noncontagious viral disease affecting the lower respiratory tract of horses

options.label: B
options.text: A highly contagious bacterial disease affecting the upper respiratory tract and lymph nodes of equids

options.label: C
options.text: A fungal infection causing chronic nasal discharge in older horses

options.label: D
options.text: An autoimmune disorder causing lymph node enlargement

questions.explanation: Strangles is a highly contagious bacterial disease affecting the upper respiratory tract and lymph nodes of horses, donkeys, and mules. It is not viral (A), fungal (C), or autoimmune (D).

questions.stem: The causative agent of strangles is:
questions.explanation: The causative agent is Streptococcus equi subspecies equi, a Gram‑positive, capsulated, beta‑hemolytic bacterium. S. equi zooepidemicus (A) is a commensal, not the primary pathogen. S. pneumoniae (C) and S. aureus (D) are not the causative agents of strangles.

questions.stem: Which virulence factor of S. equi equi is primarily responsible for preventing bacterial destruction by neutrophils?
questions.explanation: SeM protein is anti‑phagocytic and prevents bacterial destruction by neutrophils. The hyaluronic acid capsule (A) protects against host immune response but does not specifically prevent neutrophil destruction. Streptolysins (C) and superantigens (D) enhance tissue invasion and inflammation but are not the primary anti‑phagocytic factor.

questions.stem: The age group MOST commonly affected by strangles is:
questions.explanation: Strangles is most common in horses 1–5 years old, though foals as young as 3 months may be affected. Foals less than 3 months (A) are less commonly affected, and there is no specific predilection for geriatric horses (C) or equal distribution across all ages (D).

questions.stem: The primary mode of transmission for strangles is:

options.label: B
options.text: Direct contact with nasal discharge or pus, or indirect contact through contaminated objects

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical transmission from mare to foal

questions.explanation: Transmission occurs through direct contact with nasal discharge or pus, or indirect contact through contaminated feed, water, grooming tools, tack, or handlers. It is not primarily airborne over long distances (A), vertically transmitted (C), or limited to feed ingestion (D).

questions.stem: The incubation period for strangles is typically:
questions.explanation: The incubation period is typically 3–14 days after exposure. Shorter periods (A) or longer periods (C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Early clinical signs of strangles include:

options.label: B
options.text: Fever (103–106°F), depression, anorexia, and mild cough

questions.explanation: Early clinical signs include fever (103–106°F / 39.4–41.1°C), depression, anorexia, and mild cough. Colic and diarrhea (A), neurological signs (C), and cardiac signs (D) are not typical early signs of strangles.

questions.stem: Progressive signs of strangles include all of the following EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Painful swelling of submandibular and retropharyngeal lymph nodes

questions.explanation: Profuse watery diarrhea is not a typical sign of strangles. Progressive signs include mucoid to mucopurulent nasal discharge (A), painful lymph node swelling (B), and difficulty swallowing and breathing (C).

questions.stem: Metastatic (bastard) strangles occurs when:

options.label: A
options.text: Bacteria spread via blood or lymph to internal organs, forming abscesses in remote tissues

options.label: B
options.text: The primary abscess fails to rupture

options.label: C
options.text: The horse develops secondary bacterial pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: The infection becomes chronic without treatment

questions.explanation: Metastatic (bastard) strangles occurs when bacteria spread via blood or lymph to internal organs (lungs, liver, spleen, brain), forming abscesses in remote lymph nodes or tissues. Failure of primary abscess to rupture (B), secondary pneumonia (C), or chronic infection (D) are not the definition of metastatic strangles.

questions.stem: Purpura hemorrhagica is a complication of strangles that represents:

options.label: B
options.text: An immune‑mediated Type III hypersensitivity reaction causing vasculitis

questions.explanation: Purpura hemorrhagica is an immune‑mediated Type III hypersensitivity reaction that causes vasculitis, edema, petechiae, and sometimes necrosis of the skin. It is not a secondary bacterial infection (A), viral coinfection (C), or nutritional deficiency (D).

questions.stem: Guttural pouch empyema in strangles cases involves:

options.label: A
options.text: Accumulation of pus or chondroids in guttural pouches

options.label: B
options.text: Rupture of the guttural pouch into the pharynx

options.label: C
options.text: Fungal colonization of the guttural pouch

options.label: D
options.text: Neoplastic transformation of guttural pouch tissue

questions.explanation: Guttural pouch empyema involves accumulation of pus or chondroids (solid pus masses) in guttural pouches. Rupture into the pharynx (B), fungal colonization (C), or neoplasia (D) are not the typical presentation.

questions.stem: The gold standard diagnostic test for strangles is:

options.label: B
options.text: Culture of abscess exudate or nasopharyngeal wash

options.label: D
options.text: Radiography of the head and neck

questions.explanation: Culture is the gold standard diagnostic test, ideally from aspirate of abscessed lymph node, or nasopharyngeal wash or guttural pouch lavage. Serology (A) helps evaluate exposure but is not the gold standard. CBC (C) and radiography (D) are supportive but not definitive.

questions.stem: Which laboratory finding is commonly seen in horses with strangles?
questions.explanation: Neutrophilic leukocytosis and hyperfibrinogenemia are common findings. Neutropenia (A), eosinophilia (C), or anemia (D) are not typical of strangles.

questions.stem: In uncomplicated strangles cases, treatment primarily consists of:

options.label: B
options.text: Supportive care including warm compresses, drainage of abscesses, and NSAIDs

options.label: C
options.text: Surgical removal of affected lymph nodes

questions.explanation: Uncomplicated cases are treated with supportive care: warm compresses to hasten abscess maturation, drainage and flushing of ruptured abscesses, and NSAIDs for pain and fever. Immediate antibiotics (A), surgery (C), or antivirals (D) are not the primary approach for uncomplicated cases.

questions.stem: When is antimicrobial therapy indicated in strangles cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Always, as soon as diagnosis is confirmed

options.label: B
options.text: Only in severe or complicated cases such as dyspnea or metastatic disease

options.label: C
options.text: Never, as antibiotics are ineffective against S. equi

options.label: D
options.text: Only in foals less than 6 months old

questions.explanation: Antimicrobial therapy is reserved for severe or complicated cases such as dyspnea or metastatic disease. Early antibiotic use may stop abscess formation but prevents natural immunity, so it is not used routinely (A). Antibiotics are effective (C), and age is not the determining factor (D).

questions.stem: The first‑line antimicrobial drug for strangles is:

options.label: B
options.text: Procaine penicillin at 22,000 IU/kg IM every 12 hours

questions.explanation: Procaine penicillin at 22,000 IU/kg IM every 12 hours is the first‑line antimicrobial. Alternatives include cephalosporins or macrolides. Trimethoprim‑sulfamethoxazole (A), enrofloxacin (C), and metronidazole (D) are not first‑line choices.

questions.stem: Why is early antibiotic use in uncomplicated strangles cases sometimes avoided?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotics are ineffective against S. equi

options.label: B
options.text: Early antibiotic use may prevent abscess formation but also prevents natural immunity development

options.label: C
options.text: Antibiotics cause severe side effects in horses

options.label: D
options.text: S. equi is always resistant to antibiotics

questions.explanation: Early antibiotic use may stop abscess formation but prevents natural immunity development, so it is reserved for severe cases. Antibiotics are effective (A), side effects are not the primary concern (C), and resistance is not universal (D).

questions.stem: Natural infection with strangles typically induces:
questions.explanation: Natural infection induces strong and long‑lasting protection. Immunity is not absent (A), short‑lived (B), or strain‑specific (D).

questions.stem: Vaccination against strangles:
questions.explanation: Vaccination reduces clinical cases by approximately 50%. It does not provide 100% protection (A), vaccines are available (C), and effectiveness is not limited to foals (D).

questions.stem: Which statement about strangles vaccination is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaccination should be performed during ongoing outbreaks

options.label: B
options.text: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine induces local mucosal immunity

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccination is mandatory in all horses

questions.explanation: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine induces local mucosal immunity. Vaccination should not be performed during outbreaks (A), complications can occur (C), and vaccination is not mandatory (D).

questions.stem: During a strangles outbreak, horses should be separated into:
questions.explanation: During outbreaks, horses should be separated into infected, exposed, and clean groups. Simple infected/noninfected separation (B), age‑based grouping (C), or no separation (D) are not optimal for outbreak control.

questions.stem: New arrivals to a facility should be isolated for:
questions.explanation: New arrivals should be isolated for 14–21 days. Shorter periods (A, B) may not be sufficient, and longer periods (D) are typically unnecessary.

questions.stem: Asymptomatic carriers of strangles:

options.label: A
options.text: Do not exist; all infected horses show clinical signs

options.label: B
options.text: Represent up to 40% of infected horses and maintain infection in the population

questions.explanation: Asymptomatic carriers represent up to 40% of infected horses and maintain infection in the population. Carriers do exist (A), are not limited to foals (C), and can shed for months (D).

questions.stem: Carrier detection and clearance testing should be performed:

options.label: B
options.text: At least 3 weeks after recovery, using PCR on guttural pouch wash or 3 consecutive negative nasopharyngeal washes

options.label: C
options.text: Only if the horse shows recurrent clinical signs

options.label: D
options.text: Never, as carriers cannot be detected

questions.explanation: Carrier detection should be performed at least 3 weeks after recovery, using PCR on guttural pouch wash or 3 consecutive negative nasopharyngeal washes (7 days apart). Testing immediately (A), only with recurrent signs (C), or never (D) is not appropriate.

questions.stem: Which disinfectant is appropriate for cleaning equipment contaminated with S. equi?
questions.explanation: Chlorhexidine or glutaraldehyde are appropriate disinfectants. Plain water (A) and alcohol only (C) are not sufficient, and disinfection is effective (D).

questions.stem: Environmental survival of S. equi is:

options.label: A
options.text: Up to 3 days in dry conditions but longer in cool, moist environments

options.label: B
options.text: Only a few hours in any environment

questions.explanation: S. equi survives up to 3 days in dry conditions but longer in cool, moist, shaded environments or in mucoid material. Survival is not limited to hours (B), indefinite (C), or only in hosts (D).

questions.stem: Strangles became a reportable disease in the U.S. in:
questions.explanation: Strangles became a reportable disease in the U.S. in 2017 due to its contagious nature and economic impact. Earlier dates (A, B) or later (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: The name "strangles" comes from:

options.label: B
options.text: The breathing and swallowing difficulty caused by swollen lymph nodes pressing on the airway

options.label: C
options.text: The geographic origin of the disease

options.label: D
options.text: The scientist who first described it

questions.explanation: The name "strangles" comes from the breathing and swallowing difficulty caused by swollen lymph nodes pressing on the airway. It is not related to bacterial structure (A), geographic origin (C), or a scientist's name (D).
